instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
Hi.
Got a MacBook pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.
came in for not booting, no damage or signs of liquid damage.
i pluged it in 60w charger green light few seconds later orange light and booting.
battery was 0% but charging
battery status tells its normal and has 375 cycles

send it back

got it back again same issue, but hell also same happening.

customer has 2 chargers and 2 same type of macbooks
chargers Original and working perfect on the other machine.

any idear what could cause this

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message: Are you using an original or Chinese fake? Is he using a real or Chinese fake or even some 45W thing? Must be 60W

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
yes 60w Original, just made sure

funny thing now, i just came back from lunch.

green light, no fan spin, no reaction to keyboard. also usb device turned off

looks like hybernation

unpluged charger and put back nothing happens just green light wont turn orange also.

then unpluged charger and battery, put battery back and pluged in charger, and now it boots.

battery is now 100%

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>                                  16,34volt
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL>  12.87volt
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL>       12.87v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL>      12.87v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>                             16.49v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>                              3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>                              3.34v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>                                        5.02v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message: Those voltages on PPBUS are way too high. Check sense resistors <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22/51/52

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
after removing battery and charger and plugging back in it now gives 12,56 volt (until the idle state)

 if i measure <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 they both give 10,3ohm

if i measure <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> 2.3ohm and <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> 0.3 ohm  (<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> should be 0)
still does not make sense (for me) why it boots normal and works normal, and after a while it stops working and ppbus goes high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message: And measuring the resistors proves the traces are not corroded?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
pin 27/28 gives 20,6 ohms (red 27)

pin 17/18 4,2ohm (red 17) (this should be 2,2 + 0 + 0.005 if I am correct)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
hmmm after a long walk in the park with the microscoop.....

<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> was missing (thunderbolt ho gives a fuck)

and <CAPACITOR>C2304</CAPACITOR>  looked a little bad, measured and it had a short on ground.
in my opinion this is or has something to do whit S3 state.
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> 
need to plugin the board now and see if it keeps on in idle state, but Duke does this sound any way near logic for you
so when the machine goes into sleep/hibernate anything like that it completle shuts down and you can boot it up until the battery dies or is removed....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C2304</CAPACITOR> cannot be shorted as the whole machine would not work.
What happened to the 16V on PPBUS problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message:
Beep on both sides but the pad was damaged. 

Wel stupid thing is. The 16v on ppbus is not there when i just removed the charger and battery then plug it in. But after i have the machine running for a few hours it greates the 16v
ill hook up the machine later today or Tomorrow and see what it does.

but the system wont go out of sleep....

threads.message: Probably corrosion somewhere. Inspect closely and then ultrasonic it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??

has been cleaned before went over the entire board again. but nothing. (ultra sonic again)

did replace <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> because it looked like it had a hole in it.


can J5250 cause the system to think the lid is closed and to not respond to getting it out of sleep?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> high way to hell??
threads.message: Measure what <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is doing. But I think the system is crashing in sleep, which is the worst to diagnose.

seems I got a worse case one I gues.

where to start looking, board looks very clean,
